titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Passed the day between the Adelphi and Mr: Johnson’s. Rode up in the forenoon with Mrs: Adams. Mrs: Hewlett, at dinner: and Mr: Brooks and Mr: Murdoch in the Evening.

2. Came up to the Adelphi in the morning and wrote a little. Unable however to make the necessary degree of application; and must always be so in England. Dined, and passed the Evening for the at Mr: Johnson’s Mr Brooks & my brother came there from Mr: Murdoch’s where they dined. After supper came with Mrs: Adams & took our lodgings at the Adelphi.

3. Went to Church this morning at the foundling Hospital.— Heard a good sermon from Mr: Hewlett, & good singing. Returning home found Mr: F. Cabot, & J. Hall.— Walk alone before dinner.— Dined and Passed the Evening for the last time at Mr: Johnson’s, upon Tower Hill. Mr: Hewlett & my brother there; and in the Evening Mr: Brooks, and my brother.

4. Went this forenoon to look at some apartments and houses for lodgings. J. Hall, called on me. We dined at Mr: Murdoch’s. Mrs: Court there in the Evening. Mr: & Mrs: Johnson, with their two eldest daughters Nancy and Caroline, came and took their lodgings at the Adelphi. supped with us.

5. Called this forenoon upon Mr: King, and had some conversation with him upon our public affairs.— Mr: Johnson and the family dined with us. He is very unwell— Mr: Hall and Mr: Brooks with us in the Evening. The latter stayed to supper.

6. Reading the chief part of the morning. Visit to Mrs: Court.— At Sir F. Baring’s. Devonshire Square. Mrs: Court with her daughter, and the four younger ones of Mr: Johnson who are with her here at tea; Mr: Brooks, Mr: Murdoch and Mr: Hall, in the Evening: made a very large party.

7. Walk in the forenoon with J. Hall. Visited a number of book stalls, but purchased only a posthumous publication of Burke which appears this day. Moved from our lodgings this Evening to the house N. 8. in the Adelphi Buildings. Hire the house ready furnished, at 4. Guineas a week. Nancy & Caroline Johnson only, dined with us, the rest of the family being out.

8. Mr: Hall called on us this morning.— Went with him and several other American Gentlemen to see Meux’s brewery. The principal part of the process is performed by the steam engine. The works are upon a very large scale. They have 36 large vats one of which contains twenty thousand barrels. The others are of various capacities down to eight or ten thousand barrels.— They have eighty six dray horses in constant service, valued from 40 to 60 guineas each— They have lately sunk a well, from which they now draw nearly the whole of their water— Had they continued to need it from the New River which heretofore supplied them, their charge for that article alone, would have risen to £500 a year.— After viewing this curiosity, went into the City called on Mr: Brooks. He & Mr: Hall, together with Mr: Johnson and all his family dined with us at our house into which we have just moved: Mrs: Court & her daughter in the Evening. Miss Henning.— After supper we had a distressing scene, while the whole family took leave of Louisa; they go to-morrow at 4 o’clock, for Gravesend, there to embark immediately for America.

9. At 1/2 after four this morning, before we rose, Mr: Johnson and his family took their departure. The day was of course rather a dull one— Went down into the City and attended a sale of books: they all sold very dear, and I made no purchase.— We dined alone. J. Hall called on me a little before dinner. Mrs: Court & her daughter; Mr: Murdoch, and F. Hall, part of the Evening with us. My brother went to the Theatre.

10. We went this morning to church at the foundling hospital. Mr: Hewlett’s text—“sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof” and a good Sermon. He dined with us. Mr: Brooks passed the Evening with us.— We walked in Hyde Park to Kensington Garden, after Church.

11. Cold Weather. First fire.— I have been reading two late pamphlets of Barère.— Writing to my father.— Spent the day in a manner tolerably satisfactory to myself; and hope for the future during my stay here, to work with some regularity.— Read Milton’s Comus in the Evening.

12. Hall called on me this forenoon. Walk with him. Purchased some pamphlets.— Read the translation of Garat’s memoirs.— Wrote but little: not enough.— Milton’s small English Poems, and some of Southey’s letters in the Evening.

13. Wrote several Letters. Walk, and went through Bread-street, the place of Milton’s birth. The house no longer exists (it was burnt down in the fire of 1666) and the spot where it stood is not discernible by any external indication.— The street leads from Cheapside down towards the river, and is not far below St: Paul’s.— Read pamphlets. Porcupine’s Life, and began Burke’s three memorials. Mrs: Court & her daughter at tea and to pass the Evening.— Read a letter of Southey just before supper.

14. Read Paine’s life by Porcupine, and continued Burke’s three memorials. Took a walk. stopped at Peltier’s lodgings in Piccadilly and took the two last numbers of his Paper. purchased some other books, at Wright’s.— We dined (except my brother) at Mr: Hewlett’s. Mrs: Court & her daughter, & Messrs: Walker, Barrow and Kelly, all three of them literary men.— Letters upon our return home, from Mr: Johnson & Nancy, dated the 12th: in Margate roads.— Read a letter of Southey.

15. Finished Burke’s three memorials, and began writing some observations upon them. I am obliged to spend much of my time upon the transitory publications of the moment.— Usual walk. Reading Southey’s letters in the Evening. Am not so well satisfied with them as I expected.

16. Continued writing observations upon Burke’s three memorials. Read a new pamphlet of Paine’s, entitled Agrarian Justice.— Walk down in town in the morning. We dined at Mrs: Court’s. Mr: Hewlett was there. Conversation with him upon literary subjects. Read a letter of Southey on our return.

17. Went to Church this morning at the Magdalen Charity; an Institution for the purpose of recovering young women who have been debauched.— The building is a little beyond Blackfriers Bridge. I know not what the number of them is, nor the discipline to which they are subjected. The design of the Institution is good: better perhaps than its success. The young women sit in the gallery before the organ, and are screened by a green curtain from the sight of any other attendant at the Church. They perform the singing of the service.— We heard a sermon tolerably good.— Went to Hyde-Park and walked in it. Wrote a few observations upon the memorials. J. Hall dined with us. Mrs: Court at tea.— Read two or three Letters of Southey: with the map of his progress before us.

18. Reading Peltier’s account of Paris, and finished my observations upon the memorials. Went to Lackington’s book store, and he agreed to take back the sett of Johnson’s Poets, that Hall bought
for me; but that was not sent, and to exchange them for other books. My brother dined abroad. Evening reading in Southey’s Letters, of which I begin to be weary.

19. A Rainy day. Foster called upon me this morning. Went down to Lackington’s and chose my books to replace those that I return. Mrs: Court, Mrs: Hewlett and Foster dined with us. Hall sent me an excuse— Read a few Letters of Southey this Evening.

20. Had an indifferent night’s rest. Letter from my father to which I began an answer. Read Marbois’s report to the Council of Elders upon the finances of France. 18th: March last. Finished reading Southey’s letters from Spain and Portugal, and began Bertrand de Moleville’s private memoirs.

21. Called at Peltier’s to get his last number, but he was not at home. Walk in Oxford Street. Read Constant’s observations on the strength of the french Government— Wild and detestable principles.— Writing in continuation, to my father.— Read in Bertrand’s Memoirs in the Evening.

22. Pamphlets and Newspapers; wretched but necessary reading. Attended a sale of books, and purchased a few volumes— Called on Hall.— Walk after dinner to Peltier’s—his number for the 20th: delayed by the late Events in Paris.— Received my Commission and Instructions for Berlin— General Marshall brought them to Holland, and Mr: Wadsworth from thence. Read a little in the 1st: vol: of Bertrand.

23. At the sale of books again this morning. Purchased an Abridgement of Hume’s History. Finished writing to my father. Read in Bertrand’s Memoirs in the Evening. J. Hall and young Jeffrey with us at tea, and part of the Evening.

24. Went to Church this morning at the foundling Hospital. Heard Mr: Hewlett. Walk afterwards in Hyde-Park. Called at Mr: Wadsworth’s lodgings to see him, but he was not at home. He and Mr: Hall, spent part of the Evening with us.— Read afterwards. Finished the 1st: vol. of Bertrand’s Memoirs.

25. An indifferent night— Reading this forenoon, and writing a little.— Walk before dinner. Weather rainy and bad.— Read in the second volume of Bertrand in the Evening. Find it contains many remarkable anecdotes.

26. By invitation from Mr: Hewlett, dined with him and some of his friends at the Robin Hood, tavern near Shacklewell. Johnson the Bookseller, Fuseli the Painter and friend of Lavater, and the arithmetical author Bonnycastle were of the company. The conversation was principally literary. Fuseli talks much and with more than enough of assurance. He has a bright and active imagination but wants correctness and polish.— Mrs: A. dined with Mrs: Hewlett. We returned home late.—

27. Began to write some observations upon the late Events in France. Called at Mr: Taylor’s, in Crutched friars to enquire for a vessel going to Hamburg; but he was not at home. Attended at a sale of books at Tom’s Coffee House, Cornhill. Purchased a few.— Reading Bertrand’s Memoirs in the Evening.

28. Continuing my observations. Called again at Mr: Taylor’s. At the sale of books again. Further purchases. After dinner went down to the place of sale for the books. Continued reading the second volume of Bertrand’s Memoirs.

29. All the morning at home writing my observations &c. Weather very dull and unpleasant. Walk before dinner.— Mr: Murdoch called and passed an hour or two with us. He has lately returned from Brighton.— Finished reading the second volume of Bertrand’s Memoirs.

30. Went down to St: Catherine’s, early this morning. Went on board the Hamburg Ship, Frans, Captain Nommen Paulsen, bound to Hamburg; to sail in about ten days. Called at Richardson and Harrison’s Leadenhall street for a copying press.— From thence went to Mr: Leader a Coach maker in Wells Street, Oxford Street, and purchased a travelling Coach— Shall take my departure without losing a moment of time unnecessarily. I have been but too long detained already.— Began this Eveg: the 3d: vol: of Bertrand’s Memoirs, and read it almost half through.

Day. Rise irregularly from 7 to 9. Several circumstances occur to frustrate my intention of steady early rising. Read and some times write an hour before breakfast; which we have very generally at 9. After breakfast read news, pamphlets reviews &c or write till 1. or 2. P.M. Walk about the town, to pay visits or do any business, or attend sales of books &c till 5. Then return to dinner. After this an hour of leisure, then read to Mrs: A till 10— Sup very lightly, and retire to bed at 11.— This life, if I were to stay here might be improved to something useful.— But forever on the wing is a great impediment to the steady and consistent pursuit of any thing beneficial.
